results.title: The Boys' own choice
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Problem with men”.
This episode in the “Problem with men” series traces the movement to increase awareness of men’s health. In Daylesford, Victoria, we witness a successful men’s health night presented by GPS’s, chemists and dignitaries. Meanwhile, in Dallas, Texas, we visit the first Male Health Centre - the layout of the building, the clientele they attract. The centre is also involved in the regular, on-site health screenings for all male American Airlines employees, a process which has proved very successful in identifying major illnesses such as cancer. Presented by John Clarke and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: The Thing from the black lagoon
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Problem with men”.
Prostate cancer is a disease that affects thousands of men world-wide. Men with a family history of prostate cancer, those over 50, and men showing symptoms should all be screened. We follow a patient having his prostate removed following cancer detection through PSA level testing. Norman Schwarzkopf and Professor Derek Llewellyn-Jones also discuss their experience with the disease - particularly the course of treatment they chose, side effects and how they’ve coped since then. Presented by John Clarke and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: The John Thomas show
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Problem with men”.
Bryan Dawe and John Clarke introduce the delicate areas of impotence and testicular cancer. Testicular cancer can be treated early if picked up through self examination - if left, removal is the only option. Men who have had a testicle removed discuss if, and how the surgery and treatment has affected their lives. They also postulate on why self examination does not receive the same coverage that women’s self examination does. Meanwhile, impotence sufferers and their partners describe their experiences and medical professionals go through the pros and cons of vacuum pumps, self injection and where impotence treatment is heading. We are also shown how to examine for testicular abnormalities.

results.title: The Life cycle of the ostrich
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Problem with men”.
This introductory episode in “The Problem with men” looks at why males die younger than females. It attempts to find answers in youth (we follow the goings on at a B & S Ball in Derrinallum), how men live life more dangerously, what behaviour means about the nature of being a man, and how it impacts on health. It looks at what happens to men - health wise - in the under 10’s, 20’s and 40’s age brackets, as well as outlining what’s involved in a check up. Presented by John Clarke and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: New York: a documentary film
results.creator_credit: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: This five-part television documentary explores New York’s rich history as the premier laboratory of modern life. A sweeping narrative covering nearly 400 years and 400 square miles, it reveals a complex and dynamic city that has played an unparalled role in shaping the United States and reflecting its ideals. Two versions of the series are available: the original ten hour version originally broadcast in the US (NTSC) and the truncated 275 minute version broadcast in Australia. A comprehensive website based on the documentary can be found at http://www.pbs.org/wnet/newyork/
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Cosmopolis
results.creator_credit: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 5: Cosmopolis (1919-1931) examines the roaring twenties, a period when New York finished assembling the components of a mass consumer society and emerged as the cultural capital of the world. In this short but dazzling period, New York became the focal point of an extraordinary array of human and cultural energies, reaching its highest levels of urban excitement and glamour. This episode also considers the African-American experience and the rise of new media industries. The series concludes with the skyscraper war, the stock market rise, the Crash, and- in the deafening silence that followed- the building of the Empire State Building, the greatest icon on the New York skyline. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: The Power and the people
results.creator_credit: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 4: THE POWER AND THE PEOPLE (1898-1918) follows New York into the new century examining the interplay of capitalism, democracy and transformation in the wake of an extraordinary wave of immigration, the building of the subway and the birth of the skyscraper. During a single generation, over 10 million immigrants arrived in New York. Arising from the plight of the city’s most exploited citizens came reform legislation that would become the template for the New Deal. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

In this short but dazzling period, New York became the focal point of an extraordinary array of human and cultural energies, reaching its highest levels of urban excitement and glamour. It discusses the African-American experience and the rise of new media industries. The series concludes with the skyscraper war, the stock market rise, the Crash, and- in the deafening silence that followed- the building of the Empire State Building, the greatest icon on the New York skyline. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: The Power and the people [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 4: THE POWER AND THE PEOPLE (1898-1918) follows New York into the new century examining the interplay of capitalism, democracy and transformation, in the wake of an extraordinary wave of immigration, the building of the subway and the birth of the skyscraper. During a single generation, over 10 million immigrants arrived in New York. Arising from the plight of the city’s most exploited citizens came reform legislation that would become the template for the New Deal. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Sunshine and shadow
results.creator_credit: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 3: SUNSHINE AND SHADOW (1865-1898) charts New York’s history during the decades following the Civil War when it continued to grow demographically, geographically and financially at a staggering rate. It explores the incomparable fortunes of the robber barons at the unabashed corruption of political leaders in an era when the expansion of both wealth and poverty- and the schism between them- built to a complex. The episode ends with the consolidation of the five boroughs to form Greater New York on January 1, 1898. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Ades, Ric Burns, New York Historical Society, Steeplechase Films, Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
